TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi abstract beforefieldinit JavaScriptConverter extends System.Object

Docs.summary: Provides an abstract base class for a custom type converter.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.Script.Serialization.JavaScriptConverter> class enables you to implement serialization and deserialization processes for managed types that are not natively supported by the <xref:System.Web.Script.Serialization.JavaScriptSerializer> class. You can also use <xref:System.Web.Script.Serialization.JavaScriptConverter> when you need more control over the serialization and deserialization process.
The <xref:System.Web.Script.Serialization.JavaScriptConverter.SupportedTypes%2A> property indicates the types for which a custom converter provides converter services.
To indicate that a custom converter must be used by the <xref:System.Web.Script.Serialization.JavaScriptSerializer> instance, you must register the converter with the instance. If you are using the <xref:System.Web.Script.Serialization.JavaScriptSerializer> class directly, you should use the <xref:System.Web.Script.Serialization.JavaScriptSerializer.RegisterConverters%2A> method to register the converter. Otherwise, if you are invoking Web methods from ECMAScript (JavaScript) and you want to use the custom converter, you can register it by adding a `converters` element in the configuration file. For more information, see [How to: Configure ASP.NET Services in Microsoft Ajax](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/ea4fb56e-bc1d-405a-9877-00cf5e552a30).
When the <xref:System.Web.Script.Serialization.JavaScriptSerializer> instance is serializing a type for which it has a custom converter registered, the serializer calls the <xref:System.Web.Script.Serialization.JavaScriptConverter.Serialize%2A> method. Similarly, when the <xref:System.Web.Script.Serialization.JavaScriptSerializer> instance is deserializing a JavaScript Object Notation (JSON) string and recognizes that a type inside the JSON string has a custom converter associated with it, the serializer calls the <xref:System.Web.Script.Serialization.JavaScriptConverter.Deserialize%2A> method.
## Examples The following example shows how to create a custom converter for the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.ListItemCollection> class.
[!code-csharp[System.Web.Script.Serialization#2](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Atlas/System.Web.Script.Serialization/CS/App_Code/ListItemCollectionConverter.cs#2)] [!code-vb[System.Web.Script.Serialization#2](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Atlas/System.Web.Script.Serialization/VB/App_Code/ListItemCollectionConverter.vb#2)]

block.para:
When you inherit from , you must override the following members:
-
-
- provides the method that will be used by implementers of . Converter code must be able to take a value that is contained in the dictionary that the serializer passes to it, and then convert that value into an object of type . Rather than re-implementing the custom conversion code to accomplish this, you can call the method.

Docs.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

MemberSignature.Value: public abstract object Deserialize (System.Collections.Generic.IDictionary<string,object> dictionary, Type type, System.Web.Script.Serialization.JavaScriptSerializer serializer);

.method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance object Deserialize(class System.Collections.Generic.IDictionary`2<string, object> dictionary, class System.Type type, class System.Web.Script.Serialization.JavaScriptSerializer serializer) cil managed

public: abstract System::Object ^ Deserialize(System::Collections::Generic::IDictionary<System::String ^, System::Object ^> ^ dictionary, Type ^ type, System::Web::Script::Serialization::JavaScriptSerializer ^ serializer);
abstract member Deserialize : System.Collections.Generic.IDictionary<string, obj> * Type * System.Web.Script.Serialization.JavaScriptSerializer -> obj

Docs.param: An instance of property data stored as name/value pairs.
The type of the resulting object.
Docs.summary: When overridden in a derived class, converts the provided dictionary into an object of the specified type.

block.para:
The method iterates through the values in the parameter to construct an instance of the type requested in the parameter. Although a converter can directly use values from , we recommend that the converter implementer use the method instead. The converter should call this method of the instance available from the parameter.
The method enables converter to pass a property value from , and then return a value of the expected type. In some cases, a converter for a custom type might be working with properties that themselves have registered converters (for example, type A has a property of type B, and type B is also associated with a custom converter). In that case, invoking makes sure that custom converters will be recursively invoked for property data that is contained in the dictionary. When the converter has iterated through all entries in the dictionary, it returns a constructed instance of the target type.
If the converter encounters a problem during deserialization, it should throw an error that describes the problem.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance class System.Collections.Generic.IDictionary`2<string, object> Serialize(object obj, class System.Web.Script.Serialization.JavaScriptSerializer serializer) cil managed
Public MustOverride Function Serialize (obj As Object, serializer As JavaScriptSerializer) As IDictionary(Of String, Object)

public: abstract System::Collections::Generic::IDictionary<System::String ^, System::Object ^> ^ Serialize(System::Object ^ obj, System::Web::Script::Serialization::JavaScriptSerializer ^ serializer);

Docs.param: The object that is responsible for the serialization.
Docs.summary: When overridden in a derived class, builds a dictionary of name/value pairs.
Docs.returns: An object that contains key/value pairs that represent the object's data.

remarks.format: ## Remarks When you serialize a type for which a custom converter is registered, the <xref:System.Web.Script.Serialization.JavaScriptSerializer> instance invokes the <xref:System.Web.Script.Serialization.JavaScriptConverter.Serialize%2A> method.

block.para:
The return value of must be an instance with zero or more name/value pairs that represent an object's data to be converted to JSON. The converter itself does not serialize data as JSON. Instead, the converter builds a dictionary of name/value pairs that contain the property names (the string key for the dictionary) and corresponding property values (the object value in the dictionary). The instance subsequently converts these to JSON.
If the converter encounters an exception, it should throw an error that describes the problem.

MemberSignature.Value: Public MustOverride ReadOnly Property SupportedTypes As IEnumerable(Of Type)

Docs.summary: When overridden in a derived class, gets a collection of the supported types.
Docs.value: An object that implements that represents the types supported by the converter.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.Script.Serialization.JavaScriptConverter.SupportedTypes%2A> property lists the types that are supported by the converter. At run time, a <xref:System.Web.Script.Serialization.JavaScriptSerializer> instance uses this property to determine the mapping of managed types to their corresponding custom converters.
## Examples The following example shows how to override the <xref:System.Web.Script.Serialization.JavaScriptConverter.SupportedTypes%2A> property in a derived class. In this example, the converter supports only the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.ListItemCollection> type. This code example is part of a larger example provided for the <xref:System.Web.Script.Serialization.JavaScriptConverter> class.
[!code-csharp[System.Web.Script.Serialization#3](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Atlas/System.Web.Script.Serialization/CS/App_Code/ListItemCollectionConverter.cs#3)] [!code-vb[System.Web.Script.Serialization#3](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Atlas/System.Web.Script.Serialization/VB/App_Code/ListItemCollectionConverter.vb#3)]

block.para: must always return a collection, and the collection must contain at least one entry.
